advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Imagine the new world that would unfold before you if you had a powerful , portable, completely integrated computer system at your personal disposal. And at an affordable price. That's exactly what Hewlett-Packard has just created.<br> At the lab, on your desk or in your study this 20-pound, self-contained system provides professional computing power when and where you need it. That means no more waiting for data to be remotely processed and returned.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> Waiting for you, all the incredible performance and power of the IMSAI 8080. And at a price you would normally pay for a home music system : $699 in kit, $931 assembled...<br><br> <b>WORLS OF USES : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is a superbly engineered, putting litterally hundreds of applications and uses at your fingertype...<br><br> <b>GROWS WITH YOU : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is designed for many years of pleasure. With its open-chassis engineering, you can expand your system by adding peripherals and interfaces. The 22 slots and 28 amperes power supply mean that you can plug-in todays's plus tomorrow's modules. Right now, you can add a module for displaying color graphics and characters on TV, a ready-to-use keyboard, a cassette tape recorder, small and large printers...<br><br> <b>EASY TO PROGRAM : </b>With our BASIC language, you can operate the IMSAI 8080 quickly and easily. Thechnically knowledgeable ? Use our assembly language to develop sophisticated and unique software.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says that 37 cartridges are already available and that a BASIC programming cartridge is on the way (though it will never make it to the shelves). <br><br> The advert also clearly says that the system comes from America and that it offers Arcade Hits at home.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The major argument of the advert campaign was "we have a better and cheaper computer than Apple and IBM"...<br><br> True, but like many other computers of the time, the major fault of the Advantage was not to be an IBM system...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Success in the future will depend upon confidence in using new technologies. That's why a computer in the home has to be more than just an interesting diversion or even a useful tool. It has to an investment in tomorrow for you and your children... </font> <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US DEALER ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Until now, parents interested in expanding their children's educational experience, turned to expensive encyclopedias. With the advent of the PET personal computer a new avenue of visual learning is now available for your youngsters for as low as $595....<br><br> ... Your youngster will think he's playing, you'll know he's learning with the remarkable PET... </font><br><br> At the time, parents often thought a personal computer could help their youngsters learning, but 80% of the home computers sold in the 80's was used only for playing. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Douglas Reedy</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, you make me micro"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE FLYER - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated december 1983, says: "A true computing system: 3590F".<br> 3590F was approx. 547 euros, which was cheaper than a TO-7 alone one year earlier. <br><br> This box contained: a TO-7 computer, Basic cartridge with doc, Joystick/Music expansion, 2 joysticks, TRAP game and PICTOR software. This was a special offer for christmas 83. <br><br> On the whole box is written: "A smart present for the whole family". </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''<br> ''Now, go !''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #1 JAN. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The KC 85/3 was the successor of the KC 85/2. Improvements over the old system were more free RAM for programs (30 Kb instead of 18 Kb), a larger ROM (16 Kb over 4 Kb), which included the Basic interpreter (with the KC85/2, you had to load it from tape).
Both CAOS and Basic interpreter also had some new commands, especially for graphics management but the Basic remains fully compatible with the 85/2 version.
_____
Info provided by Stefan Goehler.
computer.keyboard: Chicklet keyboard, QWERTZ-Layout, 64 keys. 6 function keys (F1-F6), cursor keys. Keyboard connected to the UC through a mono audio-jack.
computer.name: KC 85/3
computer.peripherals: V24 interface, memory cards (16 / 64 kb), EPROM-module, several user ports, 5 ?'' diskdrive set-top (included own U880 system with 64K RAM !!)
computer.ports: Color TV output through PAL HF-modulator, TV output via FBAS/RGB, cassette interface DIN connector (including TTL motor switch voltage) or sound output to a stereo, 2 expansion slots, expansion interface for set-top expansion
computer.ram: 32 KB (30 kb left for user), expandable up to 4 MB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SETUP</strong></font><br><blockquote>An exemple of complete setup with computer, tape recorder, monitor (TV) and printer. Very funky colors</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The KC82 series deserved a better keyboard.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The two flat connectors are the TV/RGB monitor video output and the expansion connector.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The inside is composed of two card. The bottom one is the main CPU card, the top one holds the connectors for the front cartridges and the rear panel.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The top card also hold the UHF modulator and loudspeaker (left metal box) and the video circuitry (right box).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>All of the ICs come from former Eastern Europe.</blockquote>

computer.size: Base Unit : 380 x 250 x 70 mm. Keyboard : 296 x 152 x 29 mm / 4,8 Kg (including keyboard)
computer.sound: 2 tone generators, 2 x 5 octaves.; Stereo when connected to an hi-fi system (constant volume), mono with TV, if connected through FBAS/RGB (32 volume levels)
